title: How to get better grades in high school while gaming in my free time - Quora

response.answer_text: My answers aren’t for high school in particular but college, so here were my strategies: Find a quiet place (or somewhere you won’t be disturbed). Personally, I would work in the Commons (cafeteria) at 8 or 9 am, when there were few people there. I found that the earlier I woke up and got to campus, the more space I would have and the quieter it would be.Talk to your teachers (or professors. They have office hours for a reason). I majored in English and Geography, which may be easier majors, but I spent an inordinate amount of time doing readings and papers on how these two very different disciplines could go together.Reward yourself for a certain amount of time spent studying (e.g. I spent 45 min. studying, here’s a 5 minute break). I love reading, so I used this a lot. You may want to use this one-study for a certain amount of time, and spend x amount of minutes on your game(s).Study smarter not harder (find ways to help you learn and memorize the material rather than cramming it into your head). Flashcards, study groups, online chats with your team (if working on a group project) will help.Get a planner. Seriously, it’s the best thing to ever happen. Yes, you can write it into your phone, but what if you forget to add something in? Best 2017 Planners, Notebooks, Calendars (Blue Sky) makes some really good planners, and you can create your own. Passion Planner and bloom daily planners all have some fairly cheap planners. If you’re looking for more: http://www.buzzfeed.com/farrahpenn/gorgeous-planners-that-will-help-you-live-your-best-life?utm_term=.nm3axldz9#.axBGK5EDw has some other options.There’s an app called Forest, which basically locks your phone for the amount of time you set it so you can’t use it. For example, if you lock your phone for 80 minutes, you can’t use it for 80 minutes. At the end of the 80 minutes, you’ve planted a tree. There’s a Chrome extension called Citrus, which works the same way as Forest-you block websites for a certain amount of time, and at the end of the time you can use those websites again.

“How can I get better grades in high school while gaming in my free time?” I can’t help but wonder what else you are not sharing. People just do not go from straight A’s to failing and suicidal just due to a single recreational activity. Since you already know the answer, I will respond with the obvious. You need to focus on your schoolwork and play as a secondary activity. Just like all of the rest of us. So, limit yourself to 30 or 60 minutes of gaming a day. When your grades are back up, try 1 to 2 hours of gaming. Make sure you do all your homework and reading BEFORE you start playing. I think you will find that you have plenty of time for school and play. You just need to re-prioritize. As an aside … talk to your folks about your grades. And how you plan to address the slide. They may punish you, but that will probably play right into the new priority scheme. -Doug

You need to see a counselor if you are considering suicide over your grades. Seriously. That’s really, really bad. That aside, I balance gaming and straight As easily. It’s just a matter of priorities. Once you’ve gotten your studying out of the way, and your homework and exams are taken care of, then you can game. That’s literally it. Sometimes, when I am swamped with work, I end up not having time to game some nights. That’s fine. No big deal. I’m mature enough to understand my priorities. Obviously, all this comes with proper studying, paying attention in class, taking good notes, and asking for help when you need it. But, you already knew that, and you should be taking steps to ensure that everything happens accordingly. Once again, if you are pressed for time, think: “Is all my homework done? Am I prepared for tomorrow’s exam? Is all that taken care of? If so, do I have some spare time left before I go to bed? Cool! Let’s fire up the Xbox!” That’s all.

Thanks for the A2A. Your question worries me a lot because you use words like “sad” and “no friends” and “depression.” You say your grades went from As to Fs. I’m no expert but it sounds like you need serious help. It sounds like gaming is taking up a whole lot of your time, so much that you cannot do school work. I wonder if you’re getting enough sleep, eating well, etc. You need to talk to a trusted adult immediately. Is there a teacher, counselor, school nurse, family member, clergy member you can talk to? Although you ask in your question about balancing gaming and school work, there’s much more at stake here—your wellbeing, your physical health, your mental health. This cannot be answered in a Quora post. Please get help. Know that I am concerned, and wish you well.

You know the answer, It just can’t be done, I mean like c’mon I’m in yr 12 I start school at 8 and finish at 4, then I’ve got 6 hrs of study after that plus hanging out with my friends. Gaming, Schooling and life just can’t be together if you aren’t focused on your work. If you’re in year 8-year 10. Then all goods. However, if you’re in year 11/12 then you seriously need to focus only on your grades because everything you do in those 2 years all count to your final examination(The HSC) which is a very scary place to be if you have no idea what’s going on in school. So the short answer You really need to stop gaming if you’re in yr 12

This is a good time in your life to learn balance. You will have to balance things the rest of your life, so starting to learn how now will only help you the rest of your life. We all have interests that intrude on the things we “must” do. Yours is gaming right now. So, it will take self-discipline and practice. First, you need to be going to all your classes and do all the work in all your classes. If you need help with this, let the teacher or your counselor know. They will be happy to help — they want you to succeed. Do all of your homework first, every day, before you start to game. This will be hard, but you can do it! Second, make sure you are taking care of you. Eat healthy food. Get regular exercise; and PE class does not count. Even if it means walking around the block once each day. It will only take you 10–15 minutes, and you can spare that from your gaming. You need to be getting enough rest. Turn everything off at 10:00 each school night. Everything. Computers, phones, gaming consoles, lights — everything. It will be hard at first. You will be creating new habits and getting rid of old ones, and that is always hard. Keep your goal in mind: you want to improve your grades. You want to graduate high school, and you can’t do that with F’s. You CAN do this. If you got all A’s before you will be able to get back into the swing of things. Keep at it, and in just a few months your grades will come up and you will feel better. Best of luck to you!

If you want to make your grades better you have to make them priority. I understand what happened to you. I have fallen to the same trap. People like me and you are successful in low level classes without the need to study. But as you go for a higher class (especially in high school) it starts to challenge your intelligence. And you would have accumulated some bad skills or lacks of knowledge in some areas. So if you care about your grades, you should now work on identifying where you are getting worse and start studying. At first you may leave gaming for some week or two. Now once you are on the same foot as the class level. I would advise giving 2 hrs to studying and then 30 min on games (or 4 hrs and 1hr, depending on the games you play, and you ability to focus) and you do this as much as you want. Set study goals, and when you achieve them, give yourself a good time on a game you like. You should try different strategies until you get the grades you want, there is no general time schedule. Everything is subjective and personal. GLHF :)

Different students have different goals and objectives that will determine their activities and how they spend their time. So you love gaming. That’s totally cool. Some students choose athletics but have to spend more time studying math. Other students may choose band/orchestra as their interest but spend more time studying history. One technique that works across the board is TIME MANAGEMENT. If you want to be successful, use your time wisely. Struggling with math, chemistry or physics homework late at night won’t be productive. Mobile tutoring apps like Yup connect you with a live tutor for homework help whenever you need it! Check it out.

Make getting straight A’s a game. Challenge yourself. Take handwritten notes Transcribe the notes to clean them up, reading them aloud as you do so. Highlight transcribed notes for key points. Can you explain it to a 4-year old? If not, you don’t understand it. Flashcards can help in certain subjects. A GOOD study buddy to quiz each other can be very useful too It’s really not as hard as you think once you get into your groove. Kicked out of college the go around. Returned later - 4.0 GPADual Masters - 4.0 GPA YOU CAN DO IT! Just be honest with your self. What is stopping you from getting straight A’s? Address it! Take breaks. Stay positive. Have faith in yourself. Good luck

You need to put school first and the grades will come if you work hard enough. Whatever time you have left over in the day you can devote to whatever you want, including gaming, but that wouldn’t be my first choice. Prioritize your goals and act accordingly. If Gaming is more important than grades, that is your choice, but not a good one. Spending a lot of time gaming isn’t going to get you an education or a job, so concentrate on what’s important.

There are 168 hours in every week. All of the students who have been admitted to elite Private US universities have learned from a very young age how to use every one of those hours to their benefit while still remaining healthy. You have to reflect on how you are using Your 168 hours, and make some basic changes, and you will do fine. However, it is up to You. All the best.

By making games your reward for finishing your school work. This only works if you have extreme discipline, mind you. Give yourself a designated time to start playing games, say 9 pm. Before 9 pm, focus solely on completing your school obligations. Do not play games during your study ‘breaks’. Before 9 pm, you do not touch your game. Before 9 pm, you do not think about your game. Before 9 pm, your game does not exist. Even if you have finished your tasks before 9 pm, you do not open that game until 9 pm. Find something else to do. Read a book, play the guitar, doesn’t matter. You only get to play after 9 pm. Hope that works out for you.

Depending on how much you’re gaming and what your current grades are and how determined you are- Plan out a schedule in the morning or when you get home from school. Reward yourself with gaming by studying and/or homework (i.e. you do 45 minutes of studying/homework, you get 30 minutes of game-time). I also game a lot so I understand how you feel. It can be difficult sometimes to break away and it’s much easier to procrastinate and do everything at the last minute, but I’ve learned over time that this is not a good strategy. You have to plan things out in advance and it will become much easier (if you want, even make a physical check-list of the things you need to do. It can be very satisfying to strike things off of a list). Good luck!

Develop a study method during high school, and balance proportion with gaming. But to excel further in college, or graduate school you need to develop longer duration. You should think about the study and work as an investment. Then you will automatically search for the right jobset.

Make sure to still study. I am a straight A student in high school and I spend most of my time playing video games. Take at least 3 hours a day to study, separate from doing homework. Besides that, perform well in class, don’t be a little sit to the teachers, and be patient. Good luck.

Stop gaming until you bring your grades up. You are really stupid if you think high school grades is a worthwhile thing to kill yourself over. Don’t be dramatic. Use the gaming as an incentive to get your grades up so you can then balance your life.

response.answer_text: A2A. Are you using your PC to study? If not, stop playing games and focus on the job of being a student. Frankly this question is asked all the time, and there are already answers about improving study habits, but the study habits are useless without discipline. If you explain your daily routine, I may have other answers.

You cant. You have to make a choice… What is more important? Gaming or getting your education. Gaming is fun, FOR NOW… Education is boring for some, but in the end, you will have a great job and can game all you want in the time you want… It is all about choices!
Like your question said, game in your free time. So only game when you are certain you have studied enough for a good grade. That might mean lots of days without gaming.
Gaming can be highly addictive. once it reaches this state in your life, you cannot balance gaming with anything else.
Stop trying to multitask. Most people can't do that. Focus on homework, unless the computer is required for homework.
Man play RPGs. Play Diablo 2. You can build your character 1 hour a day. And you can study for the rest of the time.
This answer I gave says everything I understand about studying: John Penturn's answer to How can I develop study skills and discipline?
I won't serve it to you on a silver plater, You can't. Dedicate yourself to one thing, are you a strategist, or are you an intellectual. You choose, good luck Mate!
